Award.AwardTitle: US-Switzerland Planning Visit: Gene Expression and Genetic Manipulation of House Fly Sex Determination
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will initiate a new collaboration between Richard Meisel's research group at the University of Houston and colleagues in Switzerland and the Netherlands. Meisel and his colleagues will study how male and female house flies develop distinct sets of traits from the same genes. In particular, the research will focus on how gene expression - the production of RNA and protein from genes - differs between males and females. The house fly is well suited for this line of experimentation because the developmental mechanisms that initiate the production of male and female traits are characterized, the genome is sequenced, and resources for genetic experimentation are available. Researchers in the Meisel group will travel to Daniel Bopp's laboratory in Zurich, Switzerland to learn techniques for the genetic manipulation of houseflies. They will also work with European collaborators to design experiments that uncover how mutations in the male and female developmental pathways affect the expression of genes throughout the house fly genome. These experiments will address fundamental questions about the structure of developmental pathways and inform genetic control strategies for insect pests. A graduate student will participate in the planning visit, and undergraduates from under-represented groups in the sciences will be recruited to assist with the experiments. The PI will further use examples from this research in training exercises for middle school science teachers in Houston schools with large at-risk student populations.

Developmental networks often consist of conserved central nodes that receive input from evolutionarily dynamic upstream regulators. It is hypothesized that the central nodes are conserved because perturbations to them have deleterious phenotypic effects, whereas the upstream regulators are evolutionarily labile in part because the pathways are robust to these changes. Sex determination (SD) is an ideal model for testing this hypothesis because SD networks have the predicted pattern of evolutionary conservation, and SD genes and the sex-specific phenotypes they produce are well known. This new collaboration will allow for experiments in which RNAi and transgenic approaches are used to manipulate the house fly SD pathway. Organismal phenotypes, including gene expression, will be measured to test whether perturbations to conserved nodes have more drastic phenotypic consequences than changes in their upstream regulators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to initiate a new collaboration between Richard Meisel's research group at the University of Houston and colleagues in Switzerland and the Netherlands. The new collaboration will allow Meisel and his colleagues to use house flies to study how genes determine if an individual develops in to a male or female. They will also study the evolution of the genes that determine sex. The house fly is well suited for these experiments because the genes that determine sex are variable across house fly populations. In addition, the Swiss group led by Daniel Bopp has developed molecular biology approaches for manipulating house fly sex determining genes in the laboratory, and members of the Meisel lab were trained in these techniques.  

 

The PI (Richard Meisel) traveled to Zurich, Switzerland for 2 weeks in Summer 2015 to initiate the collaboration. He spent one week in Daniel Bopp’s laboratory at the University of Zurich learning techniques for injecting house fly embryos with nucleic acids to silence sex determining genes. Meisel also met with Mark Robinson at the University of Zurich to discuss genomic approaches for identifying sex determining genes, characterizing sex chromosomes, and comparing gene expression (i.e., which genes are turned on/off) between male and female flies. Meisel and Bopp additionally met with Leo Beukeboom (University of Groningen, Netherlands) to plan future experiments to study house fly sex determining genes. Furthermore, Meisel, Bopp, and Beukeboom organized a session at the International Congress of Entomology in September 2016 on Insect Sex Determination. 

 

One graduate student from Meisel’s group traveled to Zurich Switzerland for 2 months in Summer 2016 to perform experiments that were designed by Meisel and Bopp the previous year. Briefly, the graduate student used molecular biology techniques developed by Bopp to silence a sex determining genes, converting female embryos into male flies (sex reversal). Next, the student used genomic approaches that he learned in the Meisel lab to measure the expression of genes in the sex reversed flies. He is comparing the gene expression profiles of the sex reversed flies with normal males and females to assess how the sex determining genes and sex chromosomes affect gene expression. The graduate student is also working on an additional project developed by Beukeboom, Bopp, and Meisel to study other aspects of house fly sex determining genes. 

 

The project had the following broader impacts. First, the graduate student has received training in molecular biology approaches that he would not have been exposed to without the new collaboration. Second, eleven undergraduates from the University of Houston have contributed to this research. Most of these students are women and/or members of groups under-represented in the science. The training provided to these students complements their coursework and prepares them for careers in biomedical professions. Third, undergraduates involved in the research also helped develop a training exercise for middle school science teachers that uses insecticide resistance in house flies to illustrate natural selection. Over the course of the project, 30 middle school teachers have participated in a PI-led workshop where they performed the exercise.
